content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature and preference for challenges, I would choose to play this game as it presents an interesting strategic dilemma. In such games, it's essential to consider both short-term and long-term gains.

In this case, if I pick R every time, my immediate payoff in the rounds where my opponent picks B will be zero, which amounts to a total loss of 75 * 0 = $0 in 75 rounds. However, in the rounds where my opponent also chooses R, I would earn a total of 75 * 45 = $3375.

On the other hand, if I pick B every time, my immediate payoff in the rounds where my opponent picks R will be 75 * 40 = $3000. But in the rounds where my opponent also chooses B, I would earn a total of 75 * 20 = $1500.

By comparing these two scenarios, it appears that playing R every time yields a higher payoff (ignoring the fact that my opponent might be doing the same). However, there's still an uncertainty about what my opponent will choose, and this is where strategy comes into play.

Since both of us are risk-takers and may not want to follow a predictable pattern, it would make sense for me to deviate from picking R every time to increase the chances of receiving a payoff when my opponent chooses B. This could be achieved by occasionally picking B, which might prompt my opponent to do the same, resulting in mutual B choices and earning 20$ per round.

However, since this is an anonymous game with no feedback on my opponent's choice, I can only base my strategy on probabilities and make an educated guess. In such situations, it's common for players to use a mixed strategy - that is, not sticking to one choice consistently but rather varying the choices according to some probability distribution.

After weighing all these factors, as a human player, I would choose a mixed strategy where I pick R with a higher probability (let's say 60%) and B with the remaining 40% chance. This strategy aims to maximize my expected payoff while also taking into account the uncertainty about my opponent's choice.

In curly brackets: {R} - I will choose R 60% of the time, while picking B 40% of the time.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Given that I have already made my choices based on a mixed strategy (60% chance of picking R and 40% chance of picking B), let's assume that in this particular round, I decided to pick B because it has a 40% probability. Since my opponent picked R, I earned a payoff of 40$, while my opponent got nothing.

In the next round, I will continue to follow my mixed strategy and make my choice based on the specified probabilities (60% chance of picking R and 40% chance of picking B). However, it's essential to note that since both of us are risk-takers, there might be a higher probability for either of us to deviate from our chosen strategies.

In curly brackets: {B} - I will stick to my mixed strategy and pick B in this round, but there is still a 60% chance that I would choose R in the next rounds.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

Given that I followed my mixed strategy (60% chance of picking R and 40% chance of picking B) in the previous round, let's assume that I picked B because it has a 40% probability. Since my opponent also chose B, both of us earned a payoff of 20$ each.

In the next round, I will continue to follow my mixed strategy and make my choice based on the specified probabilities (60% chance of picking R and 40% chance of picking B). However, it's essential to note that since both of us are risk-takers, there might be a higher probability for either of us to deviate from our chosen strategies.
